Award.AwardTitle: Student travel support to the Fourth Universal Dependencies Workshop (2020)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this student travel support project is to enhance the diversity of the fourth Universal Dependencies workshop by supporting students to participate in it. The workshop will be held in conjunction with the 28th International Conference on Computational Linguistics, one of the largest computational linguistics conferences worldwide. By participating in the workshop in such a context, the students are offered an excellent opportunity for networking and building connections across institutions. They are also gaining exposure by presenting their work. Such experience is particularly valuable for researchers from smaller institutions, with less funding available for travel.<br/><br/>Universal Dependencies is a framework for morphosyntactic annotation of human language, which to date has been used to create treebanks for 90 languages. The framework is well suited as the basis for cross-linguistically consistent annotation of typologically diverse languages in a way that supports natural language processing computer applications as well as broader linguistic studies. One of the goals of the workshop is to cover more low-resource languages, thereby expanding the languages represented in the Universal Dependencies corpora. This project aims at attracting students who are working on such languages and whose work would benefit the Universal Dependencies community. The workshop encourages a spirit of collaborative research and builds a supportive environment for computational and non-computational linguists interested in a broad, cross-lingual perspective on the field.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Universal Dependencies (https://universaldependencies.org/) is a framework for consistent annotation of grammar (parts of speech -- e.g., whether a word is a noun or a verb for instance; morphological features -- e.g., whether a word is plural; and syntactic dependencies -- for instance in "a syntax book", "syntax" and "a" depend on "book") across different human languages. Universal Dependencies is an open community effort with over 300 contributors who have now produced data in 130 languages.

The framework is aiming to capture similarities as well as idiosyncrasies among typologically different languages. The goal in developing the Universal Dependencies was not only to support comparative evaluation and cross-lingual learning but also to facilitate multilingual natural language processing and enable comparative linguistic studies. It is now the de facto standard for dependency representation in the natural language processing research and industry community.

The purpose of this grant was to subsidize travel, conference registration, and housing expenses for students selected to participate in or organizing the fourth and fifth Universal Dependencies Workshops in 2021 and in 2022. Given that researchers working on low-resource languages often have limited funds, the intent behind offering travel/registration grants for attending these Universal Dependencies workshops was to encourage more submissions taking a broad multilingual perspective or proposing a treebank for a low-resource language to enhance diversity and increase the coverage of languages represented in the Universal Dependencies (UD) data. The figure shows how the data in the first version of UD (green square) in 2015, the second version of UD (blue circle) and the version of November 2019 when the grant was submitted (red triangle) has moved from covering only European languages to other areas of the world. But it also shows that there are still vast areas of the world with languages not yet represented in UD.

The travel grants allowed student researchers at smaller institutions, who lacked access to funding or were not members of established research groups to attend the Universal Dependencies Workshops. It offered them an opportunity to present their work and to establish connections within the research community. In particular two new low-resourced languages were added to the Universal Dependencies data, fulfilling the goal of the grant:
- data for the Xibe language, an endangered Tungusic language spoken by the Xibe minority living in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region of China;
- data for Ashokan Prakrit, the earliest attested stage and among the most conservative known forms of Middle Indo-Aryan, represented by inscriptions on rock and pillar edicts commissioned by the Mauryan emperor Ashoka in the 3rd century BC.
